course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Social Inequality and Social Mobility
course.description: Social stratification concerns the unequal distribution of resources/rewards/opportunities which are scarce but widely desired, and the process of status attainment or social mobility whereby some persons or groups come to receive more of these scarce things than are received by others. This course will introduce the basic concepts and theories in analyzing social and economic inequalities in the contemporary world.

reviews.author: asdfge
reviews.title: SOSC3880 - Social Inequality and Social Mobility
reviews.comment_content: The course focuses on economic inequality and its relationship to education, employment, race and ethnicity, housing, and family structure.  Besides, most of the topics have happened in China and USA. More importantly, the class will be organized as a seminar, with meetings focused on discussion, rather than lecture, so it is a nice class to express your opinions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor CAMPBELL is a nice person, his teaching style is really free compared to other professors. The form of the lecture is mainly discussion, you have to participate in every discussion in order to get the full mark in the participation section.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is not bad, I got A- for this course. The components of grading look like below,

Discussion Leadership 15
Class Attendance 5
Proposed Questions for Class Discussion 20
Monthly Reflections 20
Class Participation 15
Proposal for Final Project 5
Final Project 20

I got almost full marks in the class attendance and class participation parts. For the other parts, I got almost above the mean score in every sector. This is the course for SHSS students, so I think he graded not that strictly. If you put lots of effort into it, you can get A.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not that heavy. For the monthly reflection, you only have to write 300 words, and you need to submit it 3 times.
For the proposed Questions for Class Discussion, you have to do it twice every week, but you only need to write in one or two sentences.
For the final project, you have to write a 2000 word document related to the course topic, if you put effort into it, you will get a full score. Overall, the workload is OK for students.

reviews.author: chimz
reviews.comment_content:

Part 2: empirical finding: social mobility
reviews.comment_teaching: i think she tries her best to deliver the content and she prepares slides which are easily understood. However that is not enough for you understanding the whole concept. You need to spend extra efforts in knowing the whole story.
reviews.comment_grading:
i m sure TA is pretty lenient in marking the weekly comment.

midterm:
mean = 72.82, s.d. = 16.96 (i think that has been adjusted manually, not from the raw score, but anyway)

exam questions are attached here:
definitions: exclusionary closure, anomie, upper class, mode of production
SQ: 1) Difference between Marx and Weber on middle class
2) Durkheim's view on crime

MC @3X12, Definition @4x6, SQ @10X4

Final

reviews.comment_workload:
Huge amount of work to do
1) at least 10 weekly comments (based on weekly readings, no more than 500 words but i believe at least 300 words save you from getting full marks for your comment)
2) PRS sessions, so far two + attendance sign up for each lecture
3) midterm and final exam
4) group project: 1 page proposal+ 1 full written report + oral presentation

i think that is a bit overwhelming.
item 1+2 takes up 25%, item 3 - 50% (two exams are equally weighed, non-cumulative), item 4 - 25%

additional 5% for attending a guest lecture and producing a summary outside class hours

reviews.author: anday
reviews.comment_content:
The teaching content is divided into two parts.
The first part, before the mid-term exam, is about theories generated by pioneers in sociology, and further development devoted by their followers.
The second part, which contains more introduction of quantitative approach in social science research, talks about how to rank an individual in the society by occupation, income, education, or cognitive ability (IQ), and what are the variables that influence the outcome indirectly, using path analysis.

Content in the lecture slide all comes from the reading. To have a better understanding of the teaching material, finish the required reading is necessary.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Xu has much vigor for sociological studies, and some of the teaching content is from her paper. However, the slide is basically excerpts from the reading, and too much words crowded on a slide is tiring to read and recite during preparation for finals. The content is really good, and it is also too much. We could spend a whole semester talking about Max Weber, which in reality, we only learnt it for 2 lectures.  I understand it is hard for the professor to teach everything in such a short period of time, but the teaching should also be improved. More proficient English is expected.
reviews.comment_grading:
Weekly Comments (10 in total), pop quizzes and attendance: 25%
Midterm exam: 25%
Final exam: 25%
Project presentation and group report (peer evaluation included): 25%.

The midterm exam is tricky, as some of the questions are not so direct, and one of the multiple choice has not been taught in lecture but it existed in the reading. The mean was 65.9 and the standard deviation was 14.6. p.s. In order not to make it look not so disappointed, everyone was given ten more marks (so the actual mean should be 55.9). I got 92.

Group project was really in a hurry, and the overall performance of the final presentation of the whole class is not very satisfying.

Did not receive final scores and project scores.
In the end A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very demanding.
Weekly report could be a torment, especially when you hold no interest in the reading, but still have to produce a one-page A4 size argument.

Group project lacks guidance, and the process of finding related data is tough.

If you want to have a good grade, recite everything on the slide, every detail, although I could only understand part of them.

mid-term同final都係open book，唔好以為open book就好伏，佢真係有好多題係照copy ppt嘅字眼（係完整句子咁copy落試卷），所以似係考緊你記唔記得係ppt邊頁搵番個答案多d，不過都有d題目係要少少理解，如果完全唔睇靠到時搵答案就一定唔得。short question有幾題伏幾題送分：送分題直接問你definition，抄噻所有嘢落去已經得。

multiple choice (60%)
term explanation (20%)
short answer questions (20%).

最後要5-6個人做一份project，唔洗話點自己深入進行research，個人覺得幾輕鬆。Topics如下：
(i) Gender Inequality in Hong Kong (or China)
(ii) Poverty in Hong Kong (or China)
(iii) Educational Inequality in Hong Kong (or China)
(iv) Income Inequality in Hong Kong (or China)
(v) New Immigration and Socioeconomic Inequality in Hong Kong
(vi) Family backgrounds and Socioeconomic success in Hong Kong

唔take attendance，但有幾次pop up quiz，最好唔好走堂，如果淨係睇ppt真係幾難睇得明，就算唔上堂readings都一定要睇，因為佢好多時係將readings d句子copy落ppt（濃縮到冇噻前文後理，睇番readings就明噻）

有人覺得workload大，我自己覺得睇落大做落又唔算辛苦。

reviews.author: maksyu
reviews.comment_content:
This course is incredibly annoying and boring for those who are not interested in Sociology. It mainly illustrates or explains social mobility and social inequality through classic methods of socioeconomic analysis e.g. Marxism, Functionalism, and Weberian etc. You may need some time to digest some of the concepts. But don't worried, it is not difficult to understand the content overall.

If you didn't read the readings thoroughly before lessons, it is totally fine. However, most of the content in lecture notes are from the reading. Hence, you are recommended to read the readings in advance. Also, the readings provide more details which help you understand the concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
- does not speak very fluent English (does not affect your understanding of the course content though)

- spit a few sentences in Mandarin during each lesson. it does not affect your understanding of the course content. However, I may worry whether I miss something if I am a foreign student.

- he clearly explains the concepts
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance, participation, and pop-up quiz: 15%
- does not take attendance
- pop-up quiz makes you stay Lol. There were about 4-5 pop-up quizzes.

Weekly Comment (I guess it is part of the criterion above)
Each comment will be evaluated according to the following scale:
3 excellent    
2 good
1 weak; little originality
0    not submitted
If you are not extremely lazy, you can get 3 every time.

Mid-term and Final examinations (30% + 30%)
- 1 mid-term + Final, not accumulative
- open book
- There are review sheets. The format and difficulty are exactly the same.  
- MC questions, short questions (explaining about 5 terms) and 2 long questions.
- Questions are very easy
- (According to my estimation) 95% are from the lecture notes (5 % from the readings). You can directly copy everything for the writing parts.

small research report: 25%.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Pop-up quizzes are easy.
Everything is covered in the lessons and notes. As long as you are attentive during the lesson, it's a piece of cake for you. Also, he did not prohibit us from reading the notes and talking to our neighbors (just don't discuss loudly, you know what I mean).

2. Weekly comment
Sounds torturing. You are asked to write a few words (1-2 short paragraphs) only. It is completely easy to get full mark every week unless you shows that you are extremely lazy. (For most of the time, you can write the comment base on the lecture note)

3. Research Report
- you can do it alone
- Max. 6 people a group
- Workload is not too heavy if you have hard-working groupmates lol
